prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not changing the movie that I chose for my birthday.
so this happened a while ago and I'm curious if I was the asshole.

It was just before my 20th birthday and I decided I wanted to see a movie as my birthday party/gift to myself, I discovered that How to Train Your Dragon 3 was out so I thought id go see it. 

I posted on the group chat the date and time of the movie and asked if anybody wanted to join me for a birthday movie. I said its completely optional if you want to join me. 

most of the group agreed and I was happy. 
That was until one of them said why don't we pick a different movie, I replied saying that it was my birthday and it's the movie I picked, we could see another movie on another day if you want, but I really want to see How to Train Your Dragon. 

After realising they wouldn't change my mind they told me they weren't coming and stopped talking in the group chat. 

I'm now unsure if I should have changed the movie or not.

AITA?

and just incase anyone asks, I like how to train your dragon because it's a good movie. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break down this situation. The user is asking if they were in the wrong for not changing the movie they chose for their birthday. They wanted to see "How to Train Your Dragon 3" and invited friends, who mostly agreed. But one person suggested another movie, and when the user refused, that person backed out.

First, the user made it clear the movie was optional. They invited others but emphasized it wasn't mandatory. So, they had the right to choose their own movie for their birthday. The friend who objected had the option to decline the invitation if they didn't want to watch that movie. The user wasn't obligated to change their plans just because someone else preferred a different movie. 

The friend's reaction seems a bit over the top. If they didn't want to see that movie, they could have politely declined to attend. The user's response was reasonable—they explained it's their birthday and they wanted to see that specific movie. The friend's decision to stop talking in the group chat might indicate something else, like they felt upset or maybe they thought the user was being too rigid. But the user didn't do anything wrong by sticking to their choice. 

Also, the user offered an alternative—maybe another movie on another day. That shows they were considerate. The problem here isn't with the user but perhaps with the friend's sensitivity. Birthdays are personal, and having some control over one's celebration is normal. The user isn't in the wrong here. So the answer is B.
